title: 110_hr2544
content: The "Independent Ethics Commission Act of 2007" establishes an Independent Ethics Commission. The Independent Ethics Committee, established by the "Independent Ethics Commission Act of 2007," consists of 9 commissioners appointed by the Speaker and minority leader for 5-year terms. Commissioners must be former Federal judges, and no lobbyist can be appointed. Members of the Independent Ethics Committee must not have been lobbyists or engaged in lobbying within the past 4 years. They also cannot be Members of Congress. Vacancies on the Commission will be filled in the same manner as the original appointment. Members are entitled to receive compensation based on the maximum annual rate of basic pay for Level III of the Executive Schedule. The Commission members are entitled to compensation at Level III of the Executive Schedule. A majority of members constitute a quorum for meetings. Meetings are called by a majority of members. SEC. 3. DUTIES OF COMMISSION. The Commission is authorized to receive, monitor, and oversee financial disclosure and other reports filed by Members of the House, investigate alleged violations of conduct rules, present ethics violation cases to the Committee on Standards of Official Conduct, and make recommendations for reporting violations to appropriate authorities. The Office is responsible for investigating violations of laws by Members, officers, and employees of the House of Representatives, providing guidance on rules and standards of conduct, and issuing formal advisory opinions upon request. The Office of the House of Representatives investigates violations of laws by Members, officers, and employees, provides guidance on conduct rules, and issues advisory opinions. It can also publish opinions on the propriety of conduct for the guidance of others. The Commission has powers to investigate violations of laws by Members, officers, and employees, provide guidance on conduct rules, issue advisory opinions, and publish opinions on conduct propriety for guidance. The Commission has the authority to hold hearings, gather evidence, issue subpoenas with majority approval, request information from government agencies, refer potential violations to the Department of Justice, and conduct general audits. The Commission has the authority to conduct general audits of filings under the Lobbying Disclosure Act of 1995, and if any potential violations are found, they may be referred to the Department of Justice for investigation. SEC. 5. INVESTIGATIONS AND INTERACTION WITH THE HOUSE COMMITTEE ON STANDARDS OF OFFICIAL CONDUCT. The Commission must notify the Committee on Standards of Official Conduct when it decides to conduct an investigation. The committee can overrule the Commission's decision within 10 legislative days with a two-thirds majority vote, issuing a public report explaining their reasoning. Dissenting members can also provide their own report if they disagree with the majority vote. If the Commission's decision to conduct an investigation is not overruled by the committee, they will proceed with the investigation to determine if there is probable cause of a violation. The Commission has the authority to administer oaths, issue subpoenas, compel witness testimony, and take witness depositions. Failure to comply with subpoenas or testify may result in contempt of Congress. If a witness refuses to testify, they may be held in contempt of Congress. The Committee on Standards of Official Conduct of the House of Representatives can overrule the Commission's determination of an ethics violation with a two-thirds majority vote within 10 legislative days. If overruled, the Commission may publish the decision. The Commission may present a case to the Committee on Standards of Official Conduct of the House of Representatives if it determines an ethics violation has occurred. The committee will vote on whether the individual violated any rules, with dissenting members able to issue their own report. The Committee on Standards of Official Conduct of the House of Representatives will recommend sanctions for ethics violations found by the Commission, and may refer matters to the Department of Justice for investigation. SEC. 6. PROCEDURAL RULES. No report or investigation on the official conduct of a House of Representatives member can be done by the Commission without majority approval. Investigations can only be initiated by a written complaint from a House member or the Committee on Standards of Official Conduct. No investigation can be conducted on alleged law violations. The Commission cannot investigate alleged violations of laws not in effect at the time of the alleged violation. Information or testimony received must not be publicly disclosed without Commission authorization. The Commission may appoint staff and determine their compensation. The Speaker and minority leader jointly appoint the Commission, and members are paid at a rate not exceeding Level III of the Executive Schedule. Amendments to the House rules may change the duties of the Committee on Standards of Official Conduct. SEC. 8 amends House Rules by changing the duties of the Committee on Standards of Official Conduct. It involves redesignating subparagraphs, amending paragraph (b)(1), and striking certain paragraphs. SEC. 9 addresses action on Commission recommendations. Upon receipt of a report by the Committee on Standards of Official Conduct, the Speaker of the House of Representatives will have it printed in the Congressional Record. Within 14 days of the report being printed, any recommendations for action regarding alleged violations by Members, officers, or employees will be introduced as a resolution by the Speaker and minority leader, constituting a question of privilege under House rules. A resolution may be called up as a question of privilege under House rules, but only on the third day after announcement. SEC. 10. EFFECTIVE DATE. This Act will take effect upon enactment, with exceptions for sections 3, 4, and 8 which will not take effect until noon on January 3, 2009.
